SENT.plain: This report presents the treatment of 151 patients with cerebellar infarction, 98 men (65%) and 53 women (35%), mean age 62.4 years old
Occlusive hydrocephalus was diagnosed in 7.9% of the patients associated with an extensive cerebellar infarction and in all 11 surgical patients (7.2%)
Four patients underwent an external ventricular drainage with 3 deaths (75%) and 7 underwent a decompressive suboccipital craniectomy with 2 deaths (28.5%)
Mortality of the clinical group was 15 patients (10.7%)
Vertigo, vomiting, Romberg sign and dysmetria were the signs and symptoms of cerebellar involvement that were most frequently observed
Cerebellar infarction from embolism after cardiovascular surgery occurred in 57 patients (37.7%)
Cerebellar infarction, as an isolated fact, occurred in 59 patients (39%) and cerebellar plus infarction in other regions occurred in 92 patients (61%)
Magnetic resonance image was the best diagnostic form for cerebellar lesions, however computerized tomography could show cerebellar infarction in 68 patients (78%)
